awd_titl_txt: NSF EAGER: DEEP LEARNING-BASED VIRTUAL HISTOLOGY STAINING OF TISSUE SAMPLES
awd_abstract_narration:
Microscopic imaging of tissue samples is a fundamental tool used for the diagnosis of various diseases and forms the workhorse of pathology and biological sciences. The clinically-established gold standard image of a tissue section is the result of a laborious process. This work will demonstrate the ability to virtually stain label-free tissue sections and will revolutionize the current paradigm for histological analysis.


To demonstrate deep learning-based virtual histology staining of label-free human tissue samples this proposal will use salivary gland, thyroid, kidney, liver and lung samples, and will use three commonly used stains: H&E (salivary gland and thyroid), Jones stain (kidney) and Masson's Trichrome (liver and lung). This proposal will determine the staining efficacy of the proposed approach for whole slide images and will blindly evaluate the virtually stained outputs with gold standard stained samples. The output of this proposed system will be validated by a group of pathologists who will compare histopathological features with the virtual staining technique against conventional histology techniques.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Microscopic imaging of tissue samples is a fundamental tool used to diagnose various diseases and forms the workhorse of pathology and biological sciences. The clinically-established gold standard image of a tissue section is the result of a laborious process, which requires an expert's time and uses multiple reagents and chemicals, introducing irreversible effects on the tissue. This proposal developed a deep learning-based virtual histology staining method using auto-fluorescence of unstained tissue, captured with a wide-field fluorescence microscope. The virtual staining was performed on the auto-fluorescence images of the label-free tissue samples by using a deep Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), which was trained using the concept of Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN) to match bright-field microscopic images of tissue samples after they were labeled with a certain histology stain. 

The significance of this work is the ability to virtually stain label-free tissue sections, using a supervised deep learning technique with an auto-fluorescence image of the sample as input, using a standard fluorescence microscope and filter set. This makes tissue staining faster, cheaper and more consistent, also enabling tissue preservation, which will help avoid unnecessary biopsies. In addition to successfully performing various histological stains without using any chemicals, this research also demonstrated the utility of supervised learning-based computational stain transformation from one type of stain to different special stains. As this stain-to-stain transformation can be achieved in ≤1 min per patient specimen slide, it can improve the quality of the preliminary diagnosis when additional special stains are needed, along with significant savings in time and cost, reducing the burden on the healthcare system and patients. This statistical learning-based virtual staining method is transformative and has the potential to completely restructure the clinical workflow in histopathology and can benefit from various imaging modalities such as fluorescence microscopy, non-linear microscopy, holographic microscopy and optical coherence tomography, among others. This can potentially provide a digital alternative to the standard practice of histological staining of tissue samples.

Last Modified: 12/17/2022
Modified by: Aydogan Ozcan

Image

    Aydogan Ozcan
    Virtual Tissue Staining Using AI
